content.definition: Thrombosis of the subclavian-axillary vein due to compression in the thoracic outlet, typically occurring in young, athletic individuals after repetitive overhead arm activity. Also known as Paget-Schroetter syndrome or 'effort thrombosis.'

anatomy.compression_site: Costoclavicular space (between clavicle and first rib)
mechanism: Venous collaterals develop but are insufficient

duplex_ultrasound: May be limited in thoracic outlet due to clavicle
diagnosis.cross_sectional: CTV or MRV for extent and collaterals

catheter_directed_thrombolysis: Preferred in first 14 days of symptoms
Followed by repeat venography to assess compression
venoplasty: Avoid stenting before decompression (stent fracture risk)

timing_of_surgery.rationale: Allows inflammation to resolve, thrombus to organize

learning_objectives: Know treatment algorithm: thrombolysis → anticoagulation → delayed decompression
clinical_pearls: Young athlete with sudden arm swelling after workout = think Paget-Schroetter
Treatment: thrombolysis → anticoag → first rib resection (2-4 weeks later)
Do NOT stent before decompression - high fracture rate
Without first rib resection, recurrence rate is 30-40%
